com.github.alexmojaki.caseclasses.serialization

Class CSVWriter

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.alexmojaki.caseclasses.serialization.CSVWriter

  • public class CSVWriter
extends Object
    This class allows writing several CaseClasses to some form of output very easily - often in a single line. Construct an instance, then optionally chain various methods to configure the result, and finally call write(Iterable) (see for more details). For example: 
     
     new CSVWriter("data/employees.csv")
          .separator('\t')
          .formatter(CSVWriter.Formatter.ALWAYS_QUOTE)
          .write(employees);

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static interface  CSVWriter.Formatter
      This interface determines the syntax of the CSV used and how parsers will disambiguate where the fields start and end and how special characters should be interpreted.

      CSVWriter(File file)
      Construct a CSVWriter that writes to to the given File, using either the system default Charset or the one specified by the charset(Charset) method.
      CSVWriter(OutputStream stream)
      Construct a CSVWriter that writes to to the given OutputStream, using either the system default Charset or the one specified by the charset(Charset) method.
      CSVWriter(String filePath)
      Construct a CSVWriter that writes to to a file at the given path, using either the system default Charset or the one specified by the charset(Charset) method.
      CSVWriter(Writer writer)
      Construct a CSVWriter that writes directly to the given Writer.

    • Method Detail

      • charset

        public CSVWriter charset(Charset charset)
        Set the character encoding for the output. Has no effect if this instance was constructed using CSVWriter(Writer). If this method is not called and a different constructor is used, the system default character set is used.
        Returns:
        this instance for chaining

      • separator

        public CSVWriter separator(char separator)
        Set the character that separates fields in the output. By default this is a comma (',').
        Returns:
        this instance for chaining

      • quote

        public CSVWriter quote(char quote)
        Set the character that surrounds fields in the output to disambiguate where fields start and end. This is not always used. The default is a double quote ('"').
        Returns:
        this instance for chaining

      • escape

        public CSVWriter escape(char escape)
        Set the character that is inserted before special characters (the separator, quote, and the escape character itself) to indicate that the special character should be interpreted as a literal character. The default is a backslash ('\').
        Returns:
        this instance for chaining

      • nullRepresentation

        public CSVWriter nullRepresentation(String nullRepresentation)
        Set the string that is written to output when a null value is encountered. The default is an empty string ("").
        Returns:
        this instance for chaining

      • formatter

        public CSVWriter formatter(CSVWriter.Formatter formatter)
        Set the CSVWriter.Formatter used by the writer. This determines the syntax of the resulting CSV and how parsers will disambiguate where the fields start and end and how special characters should be interpreted. The default is CSVWriter.Formatter.QUOTE_IF_NEEDED.
        Returns:
        this instance for chaining

      • excludeHeader

        public CSVWriter excludeHeader()
        By default the names of the components of the written CaseClasses are used to write a header as the first line of the CSV. Call this method to prevent that.
        Returns:
        this instance for chaining

      • autoClose

        public CSVWriter autoClose()
        Ensures that this instance is always closed at the end of write(Iterable). This method is automatically called by CSVWriter(File) and CSVWriter(String).
        Returns:
        this instance for chaining
        See Also:
        close()

      • close

        public void close()
        Close the underlying Writer.
        See Also:
        autoClose()

      • write

        public void write(Iterable<? extends CaseClass> objects)
        Write the given CaseClasses to the output specified in the constructor. The process is as follows:
        1. If excludeHeader() was not called, write a header based on the names in the first object. The header is formatted in the same way as the other rows.
        2. For each CaseClass in the argument, write a row consisting of the values in the CaseClass, separated by the separator(char) character if given (comma by default), and ending in a newline character. Individual values are processed as follows:
          1. If the value is null, convert it to the nullRepresentation(String) (empty string by default). Otherwise convert it to a string using toString().
          2. Escape any instances of the escape(char) character (default '\').
          3. Format the value: see formatter(Formatter) and quote(char).
        3. If autoClose() was called, call close(). This step will happen even if an exception is thrown during writing.
        A special case is that nothing will be written (i.e. the first two steps will be skipped) if the argument is empty.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if any of the CaseClass objects have no components, or if any of the objects have a different sequence of names.
        IllegalStateException - if an IOException is thrown during writing or closing.
